blocks.text:
March 13, 1949 - Trip to the Pocono Mountains with Grandmother Landreth.
Left Lancaster 8:45 A. M; arrived home 7:00 P. M. Total trip 290 miles.

The Deleware Water Gap where the Delaware River forces its way through Kittatinny Range, seen by the children for the first time through Kiiitattatininy Rarange, seen by the children for the first time.
Phillipsburg
These rocks offered welcomed protection from a sharp wind.
Silver Lake at Edgemere has a thin coat of ice.

blocks.text: April 28, 1949 – Some of the members of American Business Club who attended an “all-you-can-eat” shad roe dinner at Accomac. The contest was declared an eighteen way draw. This marked the second anniversary of the affair.
Gordon discovers his thirty-fifth covered bridge in Lancaster County. This one spans Hammer Creek just northwest of Millway.

A late evening picture of Cindy, Nancy and Kathy along the Susquehanna River at Washingtonboro (red filter, l/100, f2.8)
(reed filter; 1/100, f2.8).

blocks.text: April 30, 1949 – The children visit Washington for the first time. Down trip by way of Conowingo and Baltimore. Return trip by way of Baltimore and York. Each way required 3½ hours.

Lined up for the ride to the top of the Washington Monument. The children (of course) wanted to climb it on foot.
Washington lined up t o r e d i g h e d f o r th e r e d i g h e d s e c o n d l y w a n t e d t o c l i m b i t o n f o o t.
The Lincoln Memorial as seen from the top of the Washington Monument.
The Washington Monument framed by the marble colonnades of the Lincoln Memorial. It rises in majestic splendor to a height of 555 ft.

blocks.text:
May 7 and 8, 1949 - Kitty and Gordon, Ve and Bill Huber on a trip to the "Grand Canyon" of Pennsylvania, Watkins Glen, Taughannock Falls, Buttermilk Falls and the Poconos.
First day, to Watkins Glen, 277 miles from Lancaster. Second day, to Cayuga Lake and south to Scranton, then west to circle Lake Wallenpaupack, through the Poconos and home, a total of 365 miles. Total trip 642 miles.
Tioga Rd.
Williamsport
We left Lancaster at 8:00 P. M., drove up the river road to Harrisburg, crossed the Susque-hanna and had breakfast at this small roadside restaurant near Amity Hall.
Our route north along the Susquehanna River to Jersey Shore (142 miles from Lancaster); then up Pine Creek to the "Grand Canyon".
We found the perfect spot for a picnic along Pine Creek about sixteen miles north of Jersey Shore. Here we built a fire and fried a large steak which had been purchased on the way.

blocks.text: A good hard surfaced road at first...but later only a dirt road dug from the side of the mountain as we approached Slate Run (above right).
Kitty beneath a signpost near Leetonia in the heart of the mountains. The road here must be practically impassable in wet weather.

Our first view of the "Grand Canyon" of Pennsylvania was from the Bradley Wales lookout. The long freight train is on the tracks of the New York Central, which follows Pine Creek through the deep gorge.

We again view the "Grand Canyon" from Colton Point on west side of the Creek. The "Canyon" is said to be 50 miles long and 1000 feet deep at certain points. After leaving Colton Point, we headed for Watkins Glen via Painted Post.

We arrived at Watkins Glen in the early evening and immediately proceeded to explore the Glen. It is a remarkable example of the erosive power of water. The park is maintained by the State oof New York. There is no charge for admission, only a chARGE for parking.

blocks.text: Above - additional views of Watkins Glen.

Right - we ate a late picnic supper of cold chicken, brought from home, along the shore of Seneca Lake. One of the so called Finger Lakes, Seneca Lake is about thirty five miles long. These lakes are reputed to be among the deepest lakes in the world. The weather had turned so cool we ate our supper in the car.

blocks.text: As we head south for Pennsylvania we pass this architectural anomaly near the entrance to Treeman State Park.

A SETTLEMENT OF FRENCH ROYALISTS,
WHO FLED THE FRENCH REVOLUTION IN
1793, WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE VALLEY DIRECTLY OPPOSITE THIS.

The scenic drive from Towanda to o Tunkhannock, where the Susquehanna River cuts through the Allegheny Mountains, is highly recommended. Impressive views are obtained at Asylum, where a group of French noblemen had planned a refuge for Marie Antoinette, and at Wyalusing Rocks, where there is a sheer drop to the river.

blocks.text: May 29, 1949 - A one day trip to the Tuscarora Mountains. We visited Kansas Valley, Fowlers Hollow and Hemlocks State Parks, and later Caledonia in South Mountain. Left home at 9: A. M. - returned at 7:00 P. M. Total trip - 225 miles. We were accompanied by Grandmother Landreth.
Nancy and Cindy read the lunch box.

blocks.text: Portland, located at the head of Casco Bay, is the metropolis of Maine. Its harbor is considered one of the eight most important in the country, is the nearest port in the United States to Europe.

Portland Head Light, erected in 1791 during the administration of George Washington, is one of the most famed lighthouses in the country. It is the subject of many painters and photograph- hers who roam the picturesque Maine coast.

blocks.text: Trip to Maine - continued.
Bridge across the Kennebec River at Bath, Maine, renowned the world over as a ship building center.
Rotting, old hulls at Wiscasset bring back memories of the days when New England sailing vessels were the fastest in the world.
At Damariscotta, we inquire the location of our cottage...and then drive six miles through the woods to reach it.

Our cottage (a camp to the natives) is "Sandy Beach" on Pemaquid Pond (it would be called a lake almost anywhere else), which is on the peninsula which juts down into the Atlantic south of Damariscotta. This section was one of the first settled in America.

blocks.text: Trip to Maine - continued

August 16 - We take a side trip to Bar Harbor on Mount Desert Island, a round trip of 258 miles. Here also on Mount Desert Island is part of Acadia National Park, of which Mt. Cadillac is the high-est point along the eastern shore of the United States. The Island was discovered by Champlain in 1604, sixteen years before the coming of the Pilgrims to Cape Cod. In 1688 the Island was given as a feudal fieid by Louis XIV to Sieur de la Mothe Cadillac, the founder later on of Detroit and Governor of Louisiana.
Lunch overlooking beautiful Belfast Bay.
Private yachts anchored at Bar Harbor, the famous resort town.
The rugged southern shore of Mount Desert Island. The rugged scouthhtherrn shoorre oof Mount Dessert Iseland..

blocks.text: . Trip to Maine - continued .

August 18 – Kitty and Gordon take a 333 miles trip to the Rangeley Lakes region bordering on the wilderness of Maine. Just northeast of this section is the Dead River region where Benedict Arnold and his men suffered unbelievable hard-ships on their march to Quebec in 1775, a march that Kenneth Roberts calls "the most dramatic and arduous march ever undertaken".
Capitol of Maine at Augusta on the Kennebec.
Kitty before one of the Rangeley Lakes which is almost hidden by a heavy mist.

Logs on the Kennebec River near Madison, Maine,
where the Great Northern Paper Co. is located.
Gordon stands beside a unique sign marking the entrance to the region.

Miles and miles of dense forests.
Millmilleses and millmillllinesses or mmillmmillenesses for denseense forestss...

blocks.text: Approximate distance 600 miles to and from Maine.
Trip to Maine - continued.
We cross the Connecticut River at Bellows Falls and enter Vermont.
We puurchaschandmaple ammanapple pie sugarranar candy on the road between Brattleboro and Bennington, Vt.
After a night in a cottage just south of Kingston, N. Y., we have a final light lunch near Allentowntown. Home at 12 noon.
End - trip to Maine.
Over popsicles, the children on the porch of a country store discuss one of the hottest summers on record.
